reviews.text: Great place, great ambiance. It was nice to hang out at this place and the server was very nice! We only had drinks, did not try the food. I recommend it.

Great ambience. Nice service and staff. Good parking space. Nice music. Good food.

I had a good experience and tasty food here.

We had a nice time here. I ate some porc 🍖 with honey. It was delicious. The toilets were clean and the decoration was pretty. The staff was nice too. Oh and before I forget, the cocktails 🍹 are good.

Cosy restaurant offering great food, great service at great value for money! There is a restaurant and a bar that's quite popular. Reservation is highly recommended as the restaurant gets really full. The ginger juice is an absolute hit (order by the bottle not by the glass). For starters we ordered the 'nems' aka vietnamese spring rolls and the chicken  brochettes which were tasty. Tye main meals were diverse. I highly recommend the grilled whole fish with plantains or the meat platter (too big for one so please share), the pork ribs as well as the Cameroonian traditional staple. The servers were helpful and super friendly. I would come back here anytime I am in Dakar.

I wanted to like this place despite the overpriced food, I didn’t care about the prices but when I cut into my chicken I saw that is wasn’t cooked. I didn’t get a chance to speak the server until the end of the meal because he never came back to check on us, so I ate the other items on my plate, but I did not touch the chicken again after I saw that. Then I gave the server the opportunity to do the right thing and correct it and he said it was not possible to change it. I asked to speak with the manager, he said he was the manager. I asked to speak to the cook he said he would get him, then came back and said I could not speak to him. In the end they did nothing and still expected me to pay.

Edited to add: after doing nothing about the uncooked chicken they gave me the bill and the chicken, which was 6,500 cfa, was still on there. I argued with them to take it off the bill, they refused. I said I would not pay for it, the server threatened me and said that he would not let me leave. I asked him to call the police several times before I tried to leave, but he refused and then the server physically pushed and assaulted me.

Day 1.name: Hôtel Parc Saint-Séverin

reviews.text:
I was upgraded to a superior room, which was more spacious. The location is excellent, with easy access to the metro and the airport line. There are many restaurants nearby, yet the area is still pretty quiet. The staff were also friendly and helpful.

The only small downside is that there’s no door or curtain in the shower, so water tends to splash out.

We stayed two nights in this hotel. The room was clean and in good repair. The location is convenient to Cathedral Notre Dame and Saint Michael.   The staff is kind and patient for English speaking tourists.  Restaurants are nearby within easy walking distance.  We used a taxi to arrive, which was easy.  We would definitely stay here again in the future.

Very nice, clean, and spacious Deluxe Room with Terrace.  For a European hotel room, it's bigger than the standard size, but with the added costs.  The terrace was excellent, with a closeup view of the Église Saint-Séverin and the top of the Notre Dame towers behind it.  It comes with a table and two chairs to relax and enjoy some coffee or wine.  Service was hospitable.  Location was good and central to many attractions forming a good base to start the day, though it was also very crowded and full of average restaurants catering to tourists.

What an amazing experience! From start to finish we experienced nothing but warmth and excellent hospitality. Our room was clean and had great views of Paris. Our concierges had excellent customer service and always greeted us with a smile. The neighbourhood was very charming and local to nightlife and restaurants. Definitely recommend for your stay in Paris!

We had a wonderful stay here. The hotel is located in Latin Quarter and quiet at the same time. The staff are simply the most lovely, kind and helpful people. We absolutely adore Ludovic and only wish we had more time to talk to him. Would absolutely stay here again during our next visit!

details.adr_address: 22 Rue de la Parcheminerie, 75005 Paris, France

Day 1.name: Le Procope

reviews.text:
The place is as beautiful as a palace, classy and elegant. The staff were not too warm or full of hospitality but definitely not cold. Even though it was very busy during the lunch hour, They were still friendly in a professional way.

The food is very delicate and refined, real French cuisine, the only problem is the limited option for non-meat eater on lunch menu.

As touristy as this place gets, myself included, most likely being the oldest continuous running restaurant in Paris since 1686 (that's 340 years) is what draws most of us in.
Went in on New Year's Day around 3pm even with reservation this place was a mad house right at the entrance.
Eventually after half an hour wait finally got a table.
With at least 2 floors and many rooms, the place was busy.  Was that because of its history OR New Year's Day or the combo, not sure?
Anyway with low expectation of the food and expecting higher prices I actually came out enjoying the food.
Braised beef cheek with parmesan ragatoni 28.50€ was very filling and delicious.  The beef was fork tender and pasta al denté.  Slightly pricey but not ridiculous given it's popularity and history.
Service was as expected very French like though staff all seem to speak good enough English to deal with people like myself.  They provided service prompt enough but not intrusive and pushing you out for the next dining group.

The interior decor you won't be able to tell it's 400+years old (not sure if it's always at the same location) and I'm sure building in and out has been renovated over time.
Overall very satisfied with the experience, the food, decor etc.

We celebrated our wedding anniversary at Le Procope, and as two history lovers, this place felt almost unreal. Dining in the same space once frequented by Napoleon, Marat, Chopin, and Voltaire ( and visited by Benjamin Franklin!) is an experience in itself, equal parts dinner and time travel. Walking around the restaurant, admiring the historical artifacts, was genuinely thrilling.
We leaned into the spirit of the place and ordered what’s advertised as the revolutionaries’ favorite champagne: the 2016 Champagne Jacquart Blanc de Blancs - absolutely delicious and perfectly celebratory. For starters, we had the classic onion soup and a soft-boiled egg with mushrooms, both light, comforting, and beautifully done.
For mains, I chose the Revolutionaries’ Beef Tenderloin, while my husband went with the Angus Beef Steak. Both were flavorful and satisfying, served with excellent sides-au gratin potatoes for me and French fries for him. Dessert sealed the deal: artisan ice cream and pavlova, light and indulgent in the best way.
The service truly elevated the evening. A special shout-out to Schuman and Arnold, who made our anniversary feel genuinely special. From the warm welcome at the door (including coat service and a wonderful table by the window) to the friendly goodbye as we left, every staff member was gracious and attentive.
History, great food, wonderful service- Le Procope isn’t just a meal, it’s an experience. An unforgettable way to celebrate a milestone.

I can only recommend this restaurant! We reserved a table for 21:45 and, as soon as we presented ourselves at the reception, we were seated immediately. The restaurant is impressive from the start, truly beautiful and very historic. The waiters were kind and nice, and the food was really delicious. I tried my first coq au vin and it was amazing!

But I would really like to point out the professionalism of the waiters when we ordered a bottle of wine, tried it and, after a while, informed them that we actually didn’t like that wine so much. They brought us an alternative that we liked a lot and changed our bottle at no cost. I had never seen a situation like this being handled so nicely in my life. I truly got the feeling that they wanted us to have the best experience possible there.

So a big shout-out to the team. I definitely recommend it and would come back again!

With the understanding it's tough to get a bad meal in Paris, what Le Procope offers is exceptional. Even though we arrived early for our reservation, we were seated right away. The waitstaff are clearly held to a very high standard, and they meet it smoothly and efficiently. And the food? Beyond words. The soups were comfort food scaled up. The scallops were perfectly pan seared, and nestled in a bed of creamy, luscious, exactly al dente parmesan risotto. The floating island for dessert was airy and light, with a beautiful caramel drizzle and a bright crunch from pink pralines. If you have an evening to spend in Paris, dinner at Le Procope is an excellent way to spend your time!

Day 1.name: Musée d'Orsay

reviews.text:
Spent 2hr here, honestly if you are not an art person, it might be boring for you. I went to see the famous paintings and practically thats all. Was very crowded tho, staff did not do crowd control.

Museum overall was very beautiful but i dont appreciate art as others do.

The view of Paris at night was beautiful!

Beautiful museum with friendly staff. The woman at check-in welcomed our two children in particular and asked about their stay in Paris.
They have neat little free lockers to safely stash your things in, which was a very good touch so we didn't have to lug our backpacks and coats through the museum.
This place is busy though. We went on a Tuesday in January. No holidays, not a weekend, and if it were any busier it would have been uncomfortable. I can see why though, the collection of Van Gogh's and Monet's is absolutely splendid. Seeing a Van Gogh in person is a whole different experience than a picture or a video. They almost come to life as you stare at them.
What is also nice about this museum is it is not overwhelmingly huge. You can see it all and take some time to contemplate pieces without having felt like you missed anything.

Amazing place to visit while in Paris, definitely a great alternative to the Louvre, as that one gets extremely crowded and even with a prebooked ticket you need to wait for an hour or even more. Here, the admission is easy and quick. There’s free lockers in the inside to leave your stuff. The museum is really big, with lots of art to see and admire. You can also find a cafe and a restaurant if you are feeling like it!

The Musée d’Orsay, opened as a museum in 1986, is a brilliant example of how a former railway station was transformed into a cultural masterpiece. The architecture alone is stunning — elegant, spacious, and very French in style.
Inside, the museum offers a complete and fascinating journey through the history of Impressionism, with works by some of the world’s most outstanding artists. The collection is beautifully curated and inspiring.
There is also a stylish café inside, perfect for enjoying a coffee, tea, or even a light meal while soaking in the atmosphere.
Overall, a truly memorable experience that leaves a very warm impression.👍 Highly recommended

My favorite museum in paris. Absolutely incredible collection of sculptures and impressionist artworks. Generally, the museum and art is so thoughtfully imbedded into the old train station building that it makes the space have a special feel to it. However queues are crazy, so make sure to book your tickets online (said by a person who stood there for 40 minutes).

reviews.text: Walked in solo for dinner and was seated immediately at the bar counter. Staff offered to take my coat into the coat room. The bartender was very sweet. The escargot was SO tender. HIGHLY recommend. If it’s your first time trying, this place would be a great first time experience. Also had the Duck w/ balsamic and the flavour was very good. The mash was amazing. I would say the Duck was a little tough but smaller cuts/ bites did just fine.

Le Comptoir de la Gastronomie is an absolute gem and a must-visit for anyone who wants to experience authentic French cuisine at its best. From the moment you step inside, the atmosphere feels warm, lively, and unmistakably Parisian—a perfect balance between traditional charm and refined elegance.
The food is outstanding. Every dish is rich in flavor, beautifully prepared, and clearly made with top-quality ingredients. The duck confit and foie gras are exceptional—perfectly cooked, deeply flavorful, and true to classic French gastronomy. Portions are generous without compromising on finesse, and each plate feels thoughtfully crafted.
The wine selection is excellent and pairs beautifully with the menu, while the desserts are the perfect ending to an already memorable meal.
Service deserves special mention: professional, friendly, and attentive without being intrusive. The staff are knowledgeable, happy to recommend dishes, and make you feel genuinely welcome.
Overall, Le Comptoir de la Gastronomie delivers an unforgettable dining experience—authentic, indulgent, and full of character. Whether you’re a food lover or visiting Paris for the first time, this place should be high on your list.

Our group was recommend this restaurant by multiple friends, we had high expectations for this dinner since some said it was the best. We had a reservation for dinner on a Wednesday night, it was quite busy so the seating was somewhat tight. We had 4 starters - the foie gras carpaccio, onion soup, snails, and frog legs. Then we for the mains we tried the duck magret and the foie gras ravioli with a truffle sauce.

In summary the food had good components but subpar execution. The frog legs were not seasoned and somewhat bland. The foie gras carpaccio was rich in texture but not in flavor - it was like eating butter by itself if that is your cup of tea. The onion soup was tasty but at first it arrived at our table lukewarm, so the cheese was not melted. We requested to be warmed up and the team was great to get it fixed - when it came back it was very enjoyable. Similarly, the foie gras ravioli was also not up to temperature so the dish did not  taste as rich as desired. The duck magret was solid and we enjoyed this.

Service was quite kind and prompt and received our feedback. Overall I believe the food can be good tasting if it was executed correctly but maybe it was an off night for the chef. Either way we were disappointed since this was our last meal of the trip and the one we were looking forward to the most.

One of the best restaurants we've dined at while visiting Paris. Our first time eating here was over a year ago. We loved it so much that we made a point to come back on our next trip to Paris. Everything we have tried here is delicious and executed with care. Our favorites are the escargot and the truffle foie gras ravioli. The service is always exceptional and friendly. The restaurant is very small and quaint so I highly recommend making a reservation as tables fill up quickly. Definitely give this place a try!

We enjoyed the dinner a lot.  We were greeted with friendly servers and food was exceptional.  The pan seared foie gras was in a generous portion and was so rich in flavour.  The duck breast was also nicely done at medium.  My husband ordered the sea bass.  He thinks the texture was not to his liking but the sides were very tasty.  Highly recommend to make a reservation in advance.

details.name: Comptoir de la Gastronomie

reviews.text: Walked in solo for dinner and was seated immediately at the bar counter. Staff offered to take my coat into the coat room. The bartender was very sweet. The escargot was SO tender. HIGHLY recommend. If it’s your first time trying, this place would be a great first time experience. Also had the Duck w/ balsamic and the flavour was very good. The mash was amazing. I would say the Duck was a little tough but smaller cuts/ bites did just fine.

Le Comptoir de la Gastronomie is an absolute gem and a must-visit for anyone who wants to experience authentic French cuisine at its best. From the moment you step inside, the atmosphere feels warm, lively, and unmistakably Parisian—a perfect balance between traditional charm and refined elegance.
The food is outstanding. Every dish is rich in flavor, beautifully prepared, and clearly made with top-quality ingredients. The duck confit and foie gras are exceptional—perfectly cooked, deeply flavorful, and true to classic French gastronomy. Portions are generous without compromising on finesse, and each plate feels thoughtfully crafted.
The wine selection is excellent and pairs beautifully with the menu, while the desserts are the perfect ending to an already memorable meal.
Service deserves special mention: professional, friendly, and attentive without being intrusive. The staff are knowledgeable, happy to recommend dishes, and make you feel genuinely welcome.
Overall, Le Comptoir de la Gastronomie delivers an unforgettable dining experience—authentic, indulgent, and full of character. Whether you’re a food lover or visiting Paris for the first time, this place should be high on your list.

Our group was recommend this restaurant by multiple friends, we had high expectations for this dinner since some said it was the best. We had a reservation for dinner on a Wednesday night, it was quite busy so the seating was somewhat tight. We had 4 starters - the foie gras carpaccio, onion soup, snails, and frog legs. Then we for the mains we tried the duck magret and the foie gras ravioli with a truffle sauce.

In summary the food had good components but subpar execution. The frog legs were not seasoned and somewhat bland. The foie gras carpaccio was rich in texture but not in flavor - it was like eating butter by itself if that is your cup of tea. The onion soup was tasty but at first it arrived at our table lukewarm, so the cheese was not melted. We requested to be warmed up and the team was great to get it fixed - when it came back it was very enjoyable. Similarly, the foie gras ravioli was also not up to temperature so the dish did not  taste as rich as desired. The duck magret was solid and we enjoyed this.

Service was quite kind and prompt and received our feedback. Overall I believe the food can be good tasting if it was executed correctly but maybe it was an off night for the chef. Either way we were disappointed since this was our last meal of the trip and the one we were looking forward to the most.

One of the best restaurants we've dined at while visiting Paris. Our first time eating here was over a year ago. We loved it so much that we made a point to come back on our next trip to Paris. Everything we have tried here is delicious and executed with care. Our favorites are the escargot and the truffle foie gras ravioli. The service is always exceptional and friendly. The restaurant is very small and quaint so I highly recommend making a reservation as tables fill up quickly. Definitely give this place a try!

We enjoyed the dinner a lot.  We were greeted with friendly servers and food was exceptional.  The pan seared foie gras was in a generous portion and was so rich in flavour.  The duck breast was also nicely done at medium.  My husband ordered the sea bass.  He thinks the texture was not to his liking but the sides were very tasty.  Highly recommend to make a reservation in advance.

Day 1.name: Musée des Arts et Métiers

reviews.text: A really interesting science museum, with a logical layout from early scientific instruments through to more recent inventions. However it is dated with very few interactive exhibits to keep children interested, and nothing notable from the last 50 years. Nevertheless some genuinely interesting and intriguing exhibits, as well as a small but beautifully laid out collection of ancient cars and airplanes in a deconsecrated church. Well worth a visit.

Amazing museum with a wide array of inventions for all audiences! I was pleasantly surprised with how many different sections there were & I loved the layout for the general exhibit. Highly recommend for anyone who loves science & engineering.

A great collection of pieces of engineering throughout history. You can easily spend 4 hours in here and not see everything. I've been here a few times, the previous time 10 years ago and again this week.

Accessibility-wise, wheelchair users and one accompanying person go free. This is usually a sign that there are some parts that are not accessible.

In this case, most of exhibits can be reached by wheelchair, but often the exhibits and plaques are at strange heights or placements. Sometimes this means that you can't read the plaque, or that the plaque blocks the full view of the piece.
We also found some text had very poor contrast for some reason, making it hard to read.

Overall though, it's not terrible as far as these things go, and there are wheelchair-friendly toilets.

We have had a lot of fun and will be back again in the future!

If you appreciate science & history, as I do - then this may be your favorite museum in the world.  Beautiful setting in an old church - as only you will find in France.  Well preserved relics of man’s inventiveness & craftsmanship.  Beautiful models of early factories & structures - all displayed in a uniform & considered manner.
Only bummer was the protective glass cases prevented taking good photos.  Had I known the Museum book (highly recommended) was only 18€ - i would have stopped trying!  This Museum may not be for everyone- but any science/technology/engineering nerd will love it.

This museum is amazing with all the different collections with artifacts on science, communication, travel, construction and more. There are explanations in every collection, and the things to see date from the 15th to 20th century! Well worth the visit.

details.adr_address: 60 Rue Réaumur, 75003 Paris, France

editorial_summary.overview: Converted church with scientific & industrial artworks & artifacts, including Foucault's pendulum.

Day 2.name: Le Général Hotel

reviews.text:
LOVED this hotel, the location and the staff. Choosing this hotel greatly improved our first trip to Paris.

The location is so perfect if you plan to travel mostly by metro. The Republic station is a connecting station for several metro lines so very convenient since we were traveling around the core of the city a lot. The neighbourhood is also really cool and interesting with lots of little shops and cool stuff to see or have a drink.

The room was tiny, but very nice. (One small complaint was the bed, we are used to much bigger beds and typically try to book a king. This was two twins put together and you could feel the gap and my feet hung over the edge - oh well, very minor and typical for the city from what we’ve seen). The lobby was relaxed and fun. Breakfast was so great - we weren’t sure we would bother with the free hotel breakfast when we booked, but man, we loved it and looked forward to it each morning. Especially the fresh squeezed orange juice!

The staff are great and offered us helpful suggestions around the area and were always eager to see if they could help. I can say without a doubt, their efforts greatly improved our trip!

I hope to be back one day. Thank you.

We had a wonderful stay at The General Hotel in Paris. The hotel location is excellent very close to the Metro and we were able to walk everywhere in Paris from the hotel. The lobby is very comfortable and having access to a breakfast room and coffee and tea made our stay feel like we were at home. The rooms are very comfortable and clean. The bathroom is excellent and very clean. The rooms have windows that open and our view to the courtyard meant it was very quiet for sleeping. All of the staff were welcoming and kind. We have stayed in many hotels in Paris and we will return to The General. Thank you Florian for making our holiday so special!

From the very first email to the moment we checked out, the service at Le General was warm, friendly, and genuinely thoughtful. I originally chose this hotel for its boutique feel and the wall art declaring “Women’s Day was Everyday,” and it absolutely lived up to that special first impression.

The hotel is perfectly located for exploring everything Paris has to offer — cafés, sights, neighbourhoods, all within easy reach. Our room was spotlessly clean, modern, and well equipped, and breakfast was great too. But what really stood out was the feeling of the place. Every member of staff was kind, welcoming, and always happy to help, which made the whole stay feel personal and relaxed.

I’ve only dropped one star due to the street noise in the room I stayed in. I didn’t ask to move and decided to see if it improved during the stay. It did slightly, and I still slept fine, but it was noticeable.

Overall, a wonderful boutique hotel with exceptional service and a warm, memorable atmosphere. I would definitely stay here again.

Overall, this is a nice hotel despite a disappointing first impression. Upon entering, the hotel seemed outdated and completely irrelevant, but throughout the 3 nights we were at the hotel, we found it to be otherwise.
The hotel is a bit outdated and small, but the location is excellent, the staff is excellent and very, very welcoming, and overall, after getting used to it, you discover that this is a hotel with a very pleasant and family atmosphere.
The breakfast is good and the room is clean.
The gym and spa do not honor a 4-star hotel in my opinion - the gym is quite small and the spa is not really a spa, but just a small dry sauna (it was not open during our stay).
The bottom line - small, family-friendly and pleasant, but does not necessarily justify 4 stars

My friend and I visited Paris in December with our six year old daughters for a girls’ weekend. Luiz and the entire team at Le General made us all feel so welcome and added to our memories and experience in Paris. The entire staff was so sweet and accommodating to our wild six year olds, and didn’t seem to mind when the girls emptied the bowls of candy (a couple of times) over the weekend. The candy kept reappearing and the staff found more ways to sneak more candy to them when delivering room service or seeing them in the halls. ;) There were coloring books and games to keep them engaged while the adults either figured out our itinerary for the day, or relaxed with a glass of wine at the end of the day. Great place for families, couples or solo travelers. I would absolutely stay at Le General again, and will definitely recommend to all of our friends when visiting Paris.

details.adr_address: 5-7 Rue Rampon, 75011 Paris, France

editorial_summary.overview: Cool, fashionable quarters with Nespresso machines & free Wi-Fi, plus a bar & a fitness room.

Day 2.name: Musée National Picasso-Paris

reviews.text:
Multi story museum devoted to Picasso and traveling exhibits, all in a historic building with dramatic staircases and views.
The museum presents works Picasso owned at his death, which provide examples of most of the artist's periods, styles, mediums, and loves. The museum also presents temporary exhibits, which it works to tie into Picasso's style and inspirations. The building also has a
cubist chapel inspired by Picasso's work and chandeliers by Giacometti.

Unforgettable art works. Über beautiful building, and very nice staff, from ticket office to café and shop. My only complaint is that there were way too many school groups and sometimes you cannot even approach the works because the kids are seated on the whole floor. Maybe you should reserve the museum for students at specific times and days?
One of the best Museums in Paris. I like to go off peak hours to avoid crowds when possible. Picasso had a long incredible career and the full arc of his work can only be seen here.

I learned so much about Picasso I didn’t know. For instance, he worked in a variety of mediums. Much of the exhibit came from Picasso’s own collection—works he kept with him throughout his life. Very well done!

I really enjoyed visiting the Musée National Picasso-Paris (part of Paris Museum Pass). It’s a beautiful museum in a historic building (starting from the antique statue at the corner of the entrance), and it has one of the best collections of Pablo Picasso’s art. You can see his paintings, drawings, and sculptures. The museum is well organized, and you can follow Picasso’s journey through different stages of his life and work.

One thing to know before you go: you must leave your bag in the cloakroom, which is downstairs. It’s free and safe, but it’s better to travel light if you can.

There’s also a small garden behind the museum. It’s a nice quiet place to sit and relax. The entrance to the garden is inside the museum too. It’s worth finding though.

Picasso was a master of traditional art, but he chose to be creative and free, "like a child". You can really see that in the artworks on display.

The museum is not too big, so you can enjoy it in one visit. The staff are helpful, and the signs are in English and French. I highly recommend it to anyone visiting Paris.

details.adr_address: 5 Rue de Thorigny, 75003 Paris, France

editorial_summary.overview: 17th-century building holding 5,000 artworks by Pablo Picasso, his own art collection & archive.

Day 2.name: Jardin du Luxembourg

reviews.text:
Luxembourg Gardens

If you don’t want a destination in Paris that asks anything of you, this is where you go.

The Luxembourg Gardens don’t require stamina, planning, or commitment. You enter, you find a chair, and the city loosens its grip. No lines, no sequencing, no sense that you’re doing it wrong.

The genius is the chairs. They face whatever you need that day: fountains, gravel paths, open sky, or nothing at all. You’re not pushed forward. You’re allowed to stop. Paris becomes something you sit with, not move through. And after walking 17,000 steps, those chairs and benches were the best sight of the day.

The Medici Fountain feels deliberately removed from time. Children play, locals read, and no one seems in a hurry to leave. Our tired feet certainly weren’t.

Luxembourg is not about spectacle or perfection. It was just a terrific place to pause and to rest.

Beautiful and peaceful garden even in winter
Jardin du Luxembourg is one of the most beautiful and relaxing places in Paris. I visited during the cold winter season, but the garden was still green and well maintained, which made the experience even more special.
The gardens are spacious and peaceful, with fountains, trees, and open areas perfect for walking or relaxing. The chairs around the fountain are great for sitting and enjoying the calm atmosphere. The nearby Luxembourg Palace adds a lot of charm to the place.
A wonderful escape from the busy city, even in winter. Highly recommended!

The Luxembourg Gardens is a beautiful and peaceful park right in the heart of Paris. It is the perfect place for a quick break, whether you want to sit, walk, or simply enjoy the calm atmosphere. A lovely green escape where you can relax and recharge before continuing to explore the city.

This park is gigantic and so beautiful! There are multiple water features and tons of beautiful statues and flowers. The pond has a large seating area with lots of chairs available so you can sit and enjoy the scenery for as long as you like.

Absolutely stunning!!! Great for just sitting and relaxing while enjoying a snack or drink. Good also for reading,  people watching, etc. Should not miss it when visiting this city. Bus stops right outside the gardens.  Check out the churro spot across the street before heading to the gardens and enjoy them while taking in the serenity of the garden.

details.adr_address: 75006 Paris, France

editorial_summary.overview: 17th-century park with formally laid-out gardens, trees planted in patterns & statues on pedestals.

Day 3.name: Pavillon Faubourg Saint-Germain & Spa
Day 3.address: 5 Rue du Pré aux Clercs, Paris

reviews.text: I would describe it as a Beautiful hotel, providing exceptional service in a lovely neighborhood. The room was well appointed and clean with a very roomy walk in closet. The classic room is small but the closet provided plenty of space and was convenient with three levels of open shelving and a place to hang clothes. The bar was lively and served up excellent drinks in a gorgeously decorated space enveloped by wood paneling, luxurious textured wall paper filled with velvet upholstered seating. As we visited in December, we were lucky to see the festive Christmas tree and decor around the hotel and all over Paris. The restaurant prepared delicious dishes enjoyed by guests and locals. I highly recommend staying here and would return.

Truly an exceptional hotel in the perfect location — it genuinely feels like you're living in the heart of Paris. The service was impeccable, easily a 10/10. Every staff member went above and beyond to make our stay unforgettable, and most even knew my name within a day.

The rooms were spacious, spotless, and beautifully maintained, with housekeeping tidying up twice daily — always with a warm smile and chocolates. The on-site restaurant was outstanding as well — don’t miss the chance to enjoy dinner there.

Overall, it was a wonderful experience, and I would highly recommend this hotel to anyone visiting Paris.

This is a rewrite of a review that I had previously written detailing a positive experience Which prompted the return visit. Unfortunately, this last visit was such a disappointment that I am
revising my assessment.  This hotel is conveniently located on a very pretty street in Saint Germain.  The decor and rooms are gracious.  Unfortunately, service is where this hotel falls egregiously short - specifically in the area of room service.  My first night ordering room service, I requested for all accoutrements on my burger to be placed on the side.  The man that took my order asked “do you want the meat?”  which I thought was such a strange question. It’s not like I asked for a grilled cheese. Sadly, that is exactly what arrived - a brioche bun and cheese. No burger at all.  When I called back and explained a second time, the burger arrived with sauce on it, which is exactly what I was trying to avoid.  I really tried to convince myself that this experience was a fluke. Not so.  The second evening I called hoping to order dinner, the man answered the phone and I said “ Hello I’d like to order room service.” He responded with “Yes? What do you want?”  What an odd and  inappropriate way to take a guest’s request. It was 10:30 PM and I ordered a crocque monsieur with fries which was on the 24/7 menu.  He called me back a few minutes later and said that I couldn’t order it because the kitchen was closed.  Confused, I hung up and went back to the menu just to double check that I hadn’t made a mistake, which I had not. When I called back and indicated that the croque monsieur was indeed on the all day menu, he said “OK we can do it for you.”   It felt like he was doing me a big favor by fulfilling this basic order.  I called again about 40 minutes later because it hadn’t arrived.  It finally arrived partially frozen and with no fries.  Totally inedible.

I described all of this to the lovely Concierge the following morning. He apologized graciously and arranged for my son and me to take a taxi to the airport free of charge.  I only have great things to say about the daytime staff.  However, whoever is managing the hotel in the late evening hours is in dire need of further training.  Be courteous, take notes, respect the guidelines of the hotel and do not go off script.  Why risk losing a repeat customer?

Lovely two night stay at Pavillon Faubourg Saint Germain. Nicely designed, nestled among beautiful streets of Faubourg Saint Germain, good food and drinks, attentive staff - can’t find much to fault here. Definitely recommend and would happily return.

Having read other reviews, I specifically asked for a room not in the building with the kitchen and was allocated a renovated room in the second building accessed through the bar. The building I was in was small in size with only about 4 rooms per floor, and the entry point through the bar felt a bit odd but I got used to it. Many Paris hotels reflect the characteristics of their original building(s), as seemed to be the case at Pavillon FSG.

The Superior room was very pretty and compact. This room would be very tight for two people especially with more than a weekend’s worth of luggage for two. Do look up the room size when booking as Paris hotel rooms are usually very small. It was small but cozy for one, and I slept extremely well - their beds and bedding are fantastic and the windows do a good job of blocking out noise. As a sensitive sleeper, I was impressed with just well I slept here. Decent water pressure in the shower albeit a bit narrow given the bathtub-shower combo set up.

Also highly recommend sitting down for a meal at Les Parisiens and checking out the bar - so convenient to pop down on a rainy evening, with good food and drinks.

Lastly, a thank you to the team at Pavillon FSG for taking into my requests, the welcome message and sweet gestures, and attentiveness throughout my stay. Many of the staff knew me despite my short stay, and I appreciated the care they put in.

A well deserved 5 stars for this intimate but remarkably friendly hotel. The rooms, the staff, and the amenities are superb. Larger hotels might offer some things like a bigger pool or health club, but they probably won’t be so prompt at responding to requests for room service and assistance with luggage or suggestions for dining, and arrangements for guides and travel. Everything was personally arranged and quickly, too. The quality of the restaurant and room service was outstanding. Virtually every staff member tried to assist us and often were fully bilingual. The hotel and s small enough that staff members all knew us and made us feel comfortable. I would gladly return on our next visit.

details.adr_address: 5 Rue du Pré aux Clercs, 75007 Paris, France

editorial_summary.overview: Upscale lodging with polished rooms & suites, a hammam & a refined restaurant, plus a fitness room.

details.formatted_address: 5 Rue du Pré aux Clercs, 75007 Paris, France
details.name: Pavillon Faubourg Saint-Germain & Spa

reviews.text: I would describe it as a Beautiful hotel, providing exceptional service in a lovely neighborhood. The room was well appointed and clean with a very roomy walk in closet. The classic room is small but the closet provided plenty of space and was convenient with three levels of open shelving and a place to hang clothes. The bar was lively and served up excellent drinks in a gorgeously decorated space enveloped by wood paneling, luxurious textured wall paper filled with velvet upholstered seating. As we visited in December, we were lucky to see the festive Christmas tree and decor around the hotel and all over Paris. The restaurant prepared delicious dishes enjoyed by guests and locals. I highly recommend staying here and would return.

Truly an exceptional hotel in the perfect location — it genuinely feels like you're living in the heart of Paris. The service was impeccable, easily a 10/10. Every staff member went above and beyond to make our stay unforgettable, and most even knew my name within a day.

The rooms were spacious, spotless, and beautifully maintained, with housekeeping tidying up twice daily — always with a warm smile and chocolates. The on-site restaurant was outstanding as well — don’t miss the chance to enjoy dinner there.

Overall, it was a wonderful experience, and I would highly recommend this hotel to anyone visiting Paris.

This is a rewrite of a review that I had previously written detailing a positive experience Which prompted the return visit. Unfortunately, this last visit was such a disappointment that I am
revising my assessment.  This hotel is conveniently located on a very pretty street in Saint Germain.  The decor and rooms are gracious.  Unfortunately, service is where this hotel falls egregiously short - specifically in the area of room service.  My first night ordering room service, I requested for all accoutrements on my burger to be placed on the side.  The man that took my order asked “do you want the meat?”  which I thought was such a strange question. It’s not like I asked for a grilled cheese. Sadly, that is exactly what arrived - a brioche bun and cheese. No burger at all.  When I called back and explained a second time, the burger arrived with sauce on it, which is exactly what I was trying to avoid.  I really tried to convince myself that this experience was a fluke. Not so.  The second evening I called hoping to order dinner, the man answered the phone and I said “ Hello I’d like to order room service.” He responded with “Yes? What do you want?”  What an odd and  inappropriate way to take a guest’s request. It was 10:30 PM and I ordered a crocque monsieur with fries which was on the 24/7 menu.  He called me back a few minutes later and said that I couldn’t order it because the kitchen was closed.  Confused, I hung up and went back to the menu just to double check that I hadn’t made a mistake, which I had not. When I called back and indicated that the croque monsieur was indeed on the all day menu, he said “OK we can do it for you.”   It felt like he was doing me a big favor by fulfilling this basic order.  I called again about 40 minutes later because it hadn’t arrived.  It finally arrived partially frozen and with no fries.  Totally inedible.

I described all of this to the lovely Concierge the following morning. He apologized graciously and arranged for my son and me to take a taxi to the airport free of charge.  I only have great things to say about the daytime staff.  However, whoever is managing the hotel in the late evening hours is in dire need of further training.  Be courteous, take notes, respect the guidelines of the hotel and do not go off script.  Why risk losing a repeat customer?

Lovely two night stay at Pavillon Faubourg Saint Germain. Nicely designed, nestled among beautiful streets of Faubourg Saint Germain, good food and drinks, attentive staff - can’t find much to fault here. Definitely recommend and would happily return.

Having read other reviews, I specifically asked for a room not in the building with the kitchen and was allocated a renovated room in the second building accessed through the bar. The building I was in was small in size with only about 4 rooms per floor, and the entry point through the bar felt a bit odd but I got used to it. Many Paris hotels reflect the characteristics of their original building(s), as seemed to be the case at Pavillon FSG.

The Superior room was very pretty and compact. This room would be very tight for two people especially with more than a weekend’s worth of luggage for two. Do look up the room size when booking as Paris hotel rooms are usually very small. It was small but cozy for one, and I slept extremely well - their beds and bedding are fantastic and the windows do a good job of blocking out noise. As a sensitive sleeper, I was impressed with just well I slept here. Decent water pressure in the shower albeit a bit narrow given the bathtub-shower combo set up.

Also highly recommend sitting down for a meal at Les Parisiens and checking out the bar - so convenient to pop down on a rainy evening, with good food and drinks.

Lastly, a thank you to the team at Pavillon FSG for taking into my requests, the welcome message and sweet gestures, and attentiveness throughout my stay. Many of the staff knew me despite my short stay, and I appreciated the care they put in.

A well deserved 5 stars for this intimate but remarkably friendly hotel. The rooms, the staff, and the amenities are superb. Larger hotels might offer some things like a bigger pool or health club, but they probably won’t be so prompt at responding to requests for room service and assistance with luggage or suggestions for dining, and arrangements for guides and travel. Everything was personally arranged and quickly, too. The quality of the restaurant and room service was outstanding. Virtually every staff member tried to assist us and often were fully bilingual. The hotel and s small enough that staff members all knew us and made us feel comfortable. I would gladly return on our next visit.

Day 3.name: Sainte-Chapelle

reviews.text: Really really really beautiful chapel to visit in Paris. You definitely need to book a ticket in advance if you can! I had it, and I had to queue outside for 20min. The inside of the buiding is small, and it gets pretty crowded, but still worth it! The staff is nice and helpful

This small chapel was originally built exclusively for the royal family, including the king and princes, and is now open to the public. I genuinely felt lucky to be able to visit it. In many ways, it feels much more elaborate and “fancy” than Notre-Dame.

The stained glass is absolutely overwhelming — in a beautiful way. There’s so much visual information that I could only focus on one section at a time before feeling saturated. After a full day of visiting multiple museums, it honestly takes a lot of patience to fully absorb a place like this.

If you have the time and energy, it’s definitely worth seeing at least once. That said, the ticket price feels a bit high for the duration of the visit. Also worth mentioning: the security check is extremely intense — airport-level strict. My water bottle was confiscated, which was frustrating and honestly a little heartbreaking. I’m not sure why the security needs to be that extreme, but it’s something to be prepared for.

The Sainte-Chapelle is a truly remarkable place, renowned for its stunning stained glass windows. It’s best visited on a bright day to fully appreciate the vivid colors and intricate designs that come to life in the sunlight.

Upon entering, you’re greeted by a smaller downstairs room filled with merchandise stalls, which unfortunately detracts from the chapel’s peaceful atmosphere. The contrast between the commercial area and the sacred space feels somewhat out of place. However, in the corner of the room, a narrow spiral staircase leads up to the main chapel, where the real beauty lies.

The queuing process could be better managed. Despite having booked a timed entry slot, I still found myself waiting well past my allotted time before being allowed in. It felt disorganized, especially for those who had planned their visit around their scheduled time.

I would have loved to spend more time reading the informative brochures, but unfortunately, they were only available in other languages. I found myself checking repeatedly to see if anyone had returned any English-language versions. It would have been far more enjoyable if they had laminated additional copies or offered the information through an app. This small addition would have greatly enhanced the overall experience.

•	A Gothic masterpiece: Built between 1242 and 1248 by King Louis IX (Saint Louis) to house precious Christian relics — including the Crown of Thorns — Sainte-Chapelle is one of the finest examples of Rayonnant Gothic architecture.
•	Unforgettable stained glass: The upper chapel features 15 towering stained-glass windows, each over 15 meters tall, illustrating more than 1,100 biblical scenes. When sunlight filters through, the entire space glows in a kaleidoscope of reds, blues, and purples — an experience visitors often describe as “spiritual” or “otherworldly.”
•	Compact yet awe-inspiring: Unlike sprawling cathedrals, Sainte-Chapelle is intimate. You don’t just see it — you feel it envelop you in color and light.
•	Central location: Located on the Île de la Cité, next to the Palais de Justice and a few steps from Notre-Dame, it’s easy to combine with other major Paris attractions.
•	Historical significance: As the private royal chapel of the French kings, it represents both religious devotion and the peak of medieval artistry.

⸻

⚠️ Things to keep in mind
•	Crowds and queues: Sainte-Chapelle is small and extremely popular — lines form early, and the chapel can feel packed, especially mid-day.
•	Security checks: Entry is through the Palais de Justice complex, so airport-style security applies. Arrive early to avoid delays.
•	Limited visit time: The experience, while stunning, is short — most visitors spend about 30–45 minutes inside.
•	Lighting conditions vary: The stained glass looks best on sunny days (late morning to mid-afternoon). On cloudy days, colors appear softer and less vivid but still atmospheric.
•	Lower chapel first: The entrance leads you through the modest lower chapel before you ascend to the breathtaking upper chapel — don’t rush; the contrast enhances the reveal.

A Breathtaking Masterpiece of Light and Color!

Sainte-Chapelle is one of the most stunning sites in Paris — truly a hidden jewel of Gothic architecture. The moment you step inside, you’re surrounded by a dazzling display of stained glass that fills the chapel with radiant light and color. Each panel tells a story from the Bible, creating a sense of awe and serenity unlike anywhere else.

The upper chapel is especially mesmerizing, with its towering windows and intricate details that make you feel as if you’re standing inside a jewel box. Don’t let the long line discourage you — it’s absolutely worth the wait.

Even after visiting the grand cathedrals of Europe, Sainte-Chapelle stands out as one of the most unforgettable experiences. A must-see in Paris — peaceful, spiritual, and breathtakingly beautiful!

Day 3.name: Shakespeare and Company

reviews.text: Magical experience! No photos allowed inside which give you the purest experience of a bookstore. You can READ ALL BOOK, no plastic wrapping the book. There is a reading room upstairs and very comfortable. You can come without purchasing. Reasonable book price. Wide collection. Love it love it!!

This bookstore has a big reputation, but the reality is more underwhelming. The interior feels quite worn and cluttered, with several single beds repurposed as sofas. There is a small reading area upstairs, and even if you don’t actually read, sitting quietly for a moment to absorb the Parisian atmosphere can be pleasant.

Photography is not allowed inside, which limits the experience a bit. Overall, it’s still worth a quick visit for the atmosphere alone. If you speak French, you might find a book worth buying; if not, the tote bags and small souvenirs are probably the better takeaway.

We love this book store! It has so much character, so much charm and magic.  You can’t take pictures inside so it’s definitely worth seeing for yourself! They have a great selection of books and just a great souvenir when visiting Paris.  The kids section is also very charming.  Lots of nooks to sit and read. So if you want a rest while touring, this is a great spot.  There will be a line to get in but it moves fast.  It’s small but so so charming. My kids definitely enjoyed going in there.  Upstairs is a reading room with lots of old book collection and typewriters throughout.  Just so cool the be in there. There’s also a cafe next door.

The staff book recommendations are top notch. I loved the reading room upstairs where you can sit and enjoy a borrowed book. No pictures allowed inside, so out away your phones and cameras. Go early, because it's a historic building and a limited number of people are allowed in at a time. They don't give you VAT forms.

I could only spend sadly 15 minutes in the store, but being surrounded by all the books and the franchise was magical. The interior wasn't very spacious, and photography was forbidden, just to make sure all customers could enjoy the sea of knowledge and the lovely atmosphere.

details.adr_address: 37 Rue de la Bûcherie, 75005 Paris, France

editorial_summary.overview: Iconic, English-language bookstore stocking new & used titles in bohemian surrounds since 1951.

Very nice museum, very interesting. It's small but there are lots of things, souvenirs, letters... very interesting. I recommend it.

A small museum that's definitely worth a visit. It offers both a temporary section and the permanent exhibition.
The museum is modern and well-illustrated. One section is devoted to local history, which is undoubtedly the most interesting.
The temporary exhibition was dedicated to Michelin during the war. Absolutely essential!

Excellent guided tour on the theme of "Michelin in the Second World War." A wealth of fascinating information provided insights into the company's history and its applications to French industry, particularly the rubber and tire industries. The museum is small, and our group of only about ten people made it ideal for the presentation, which expanded upon the various themes explored on the panels and in the display cases. A must-see exhibition to complement the Michelin Adventure museum visit, which we did on the same day.

Small museum with lots of reading material, not suitable for young children
But nonetheless fascinating

The welcome is also very warm

If you’re looking for a refined yet affordable French dining experience, this Bib Gourmand restaurant is a gem. Their menu, featuring options of fish or meat, delivers fantastic food at a price that’s hard to believe for the quality on offer. Every dish is carefully prepared, showcasing the chef’s attention to detail and passion for traditional French cuisine.

The restaurant strikes a perfect balance between sophistication and accessibility. Whether you’re craving a perfectly cooked piece of fish or a hearty, flavor-packed meat dish, this is a spot where you’ll leave impressed without breaking the bank. A wonderful choice for anyone seeking a memorable French meal.

Also, if your dog is well behaved, it will be welcomed too!
Great experience, the food was so good flavoured. Service relaxed and friendly. Price surprisingly low for high quality food. Thank you @chardonnay
worth to taste delicious food. Very good lunch menu at very reasonable price. Two servers with smile all the time.
Cozy place and food was wonderful
First timefor me trying French food, it was a great experience, and the staff are very nice 😍👍👍👍

Day 2.name: Basilique Notre-Dame du Port
Day 2.address: 4 Rue Notre Dame du Port, Clermont-Ferrand

reviews.text: Beautiful old medieval  church. Free entry. Beautiful stained windows and decorative ceilings. Worth a visit

Truly amazing church of roman style. No further alterations in later centuries, but original as it was in 1140 when it was built. Ther is also a crypt below the apsis. The ceiling is very beautiful , in the area of the choir it is obvious that the architect had difficulties to combine the different elements into a cross shape. A must see when in clermont ferrand.

Visiting from Rue Robertus gives you a better view of the basilica and it's unique geometric shaped architecture. It was empty during the weekend giving a peaceful atmosphere to the visit. You have an access to the crypt too! Overall, it's a lovely romanesque styled basilica worth visiting for some peace :)

A beautiful romanesque basilica with typical chevets and mosaics, among the five greatest churches in Auvergne (Issoire, Orcival, Saint-Nectaire, and Saint-Saturnin). Founded in the 6th century, burned down and rebuilt around the 12th, the building has been restored (questionably) in the 19th century, finally a major restoration programme took place in the church interior at the beginning of the 21st century (to clean the stonework and remove the 19th century cement adds) after the basilica was added to the UNESCO World Heritage (1998).
Lovely small basilica with stained glass, shrines, and sculptures.

details.formatted_address: 4 Rue Notre Dame du Port, 63000 Clermont-Ferrand, France
details.name: Basilique Notre-Dame du Port

reviews.text: Beautiful old medieval  church. Free entry. Beautiful stained windows and decorative ceilings. Worth a visit

Truly amazing church of roman style. No further alterations in later centuries, but original as it was in 1140 when it was built. Ther is also a crypt below the apsis. The ceiling is very beautiful , in the area of the choir it is obvious that the architect had difficulties to combine the different elements into a cross shape. A must see when in clermont ferrand.

Visiting from Rue Robertus gives you a better view of the basilica and it's unique geometric shaped architecture. It was empty during the weekend giving a peaceful atmosphere to the visit. You have an access to the crypt too! Overall, it's a lovely romanesque styled basilica worth visiting for some peace :)

reviews.text: For a very long time I would have liked to be able to visit the interior of this splendid building and now I took advantage of the exhibition that is taking place to enjoy the beauty of the place.  The exhibition can be visited for free
A truly beautiful photography exhibition in a charming building! A wonderful discovery; I had a lovely time! I highly recommend it!
Besides being a beautiful place, well located in the city center, it always has very interesting photography exhibitions. Admission is free. I highly recommend it.
É um prédio antigo e histórico. A entrada é gratuita e tem exposição de fotografia. Muito bonito vale a pena visitar. Tem bastante degraus para subir e não vi elevador.

Exhibition visited on the photographic work of Patrick Tourneboeuf, in residence at the Fontfreyde hotel. Different parts (meanwhile, steles, monumentum) presenting an interesting angle on places that we no longer see because they are abandoned (factory site Cataroux Michelin and other disused sites, or under renovation), or invisible because everyday (mortuary steles all over France). Beautiful immersion for the "monumentum" animation set to music. As a bonus, "empty your bag" on the ground floor, interesting and fun exhibition (we were left a little hungry, there would be so much to develop). And always the shelves of books on photography with free access. All in a place that is worth the detour in itself. A visit to do for all these reasons!

Day 3.name: 5&5 Rooftop chambres d'hôtes
Day 3.address: Zone de livraison 1, 5 Rue Jean Rochon, Clermont-Ferrand

reviews.text: Excellent and stylish stop-over location during our trip to Spain. Very friendly host and an amazing view from the rooftop terrace.

I wish I could rate this higher than a 5. This was by far the best hotel experience I had on an Europe trip which included two '5 star' hotels. My friend and I were extremely late to check in (think 4 in the morning) due to terrible weather and train conditions. Despite this, we were let in and given access to our rooms even when we were well beyond check-in hours. The rooftop view is the best in the city and everything from the decorations to the bathroom utilities are top-class and new. Couldn't recommend this place strongly enough!
Lovely place tucked away within a few minutes walk from the main square, cathedral and market. Wonderfully appointed with a friendly and gracious host!
Top

An exceptional location in the heart of Clermont. The Kyoto room is fantastic. Exactly as pictured and perfect for couples.
The rooftop offers a 360-degree view encompassing the cathedral and the Puy-de-Dôme.
The host is knowledgeable and a great communicator. Welcoming, unpretentious, and refined. A definite 5-star experience.

Day 3.name: Cathédrale Notre-Dame-de-l'Assomption
Day 3.address: Clermont-Ferrand Cathedral, Pl. de la Victoire, Clermont-Ferrand

reviews.text: Beautiful cathedral with fabulous stained glass window and alter area. Lots of bars and eateries surround.

I have a beautiful experience to visit over here. Such a lovely and amazing place. Very impressive and Attractive. This church is so cool i highly recommend to visit this. You can go inside as well to look. I personally prefer summer time to visit cause winter time is so could over there. Cathedral Of our lady of the assumption is really good and it's my pleasure to visit here. Thanks

Oh boy! This cathedral is the identity of Clermont-Ferrand and rightly so. Built with lava stone, it gives a dark colour to the cathedral making it unique to the other cathedrals in France which is usually built with limestone. It's a gothic masterpiece and one of the tallest in France. Not to mention, the stained glass windows inside the cathedral was so colourful. I'm impressed!

Stunning church with daily Mass and adoration. Unlike most other cathedrals Mass is held on the main altar which is beautiful.

Unfortunately like most cathedrals they’ve picked chairs instead of pews, making it difficult to kneel.

The church is stunning and built from lava stone, there is beautiful artwork and architecture to admire inside. The high ceilings reach all the way up to heaven, bringing us up there for Mass.

This magnificent basilica leaves an indelible impression on all who are fortunate enough to experience its splendor.
Standing tall against the skyline of Clermont-Ferrand, the Basilique Notre-Dame de l'Assomption is a testament to the city's rich history and enduring spiritual significance. It is one of the most iconic landmarks in the region.

Constructed from the distinctive black volcanic stone native to the Auvergne region, the basilica's Gothic facade commands attention with its intricate detailing and imposing presence. Stepping through its grand entrance, visitors are enveloped in a sense of solemnity and tranquility, as light filters through stained glass windows.

If you find yourself in Clermont-Ferrand, a visit to the Basilique Notre-Dame de l'Assomption is an absolute must.
